awd_titl_txt: Scholars of Excellence in Engineering and Computer Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Gannon University continues the Scholars of Excellence in Engineering and Computer Science (SEECS) scholarship program.  Over the five-year grant period, the program supports 20 academically promising students per year.  The goals of the SEECS program are to: 1) increase the enrollment of financially needy, academically talented students in engineering and computer science programs; 2) assist students through scholarships and rigorous academic support, and 3) foster professional development to prepare students for STEM careers.  

The cornerstone of the program is the Professional and Personal Enrichment Seminars which offer a single, shared experience for all scholars.  Developmental workshops build social, academic, and career skills.  Organizational and leadership skills are developed through team activities, colloquium speakers and field trips.  The seminar includes a service-learning team design activity.  Paired with a community non-profit organization, the students identify and design a solution to a STEM-related problem to aid the organization.  Such enrichment activities make students more aware of the role of STEM professionals and help them develop social and leadership skills.  

The project impacts are multifold: 1) to enhance the referral network and partnerships with the Erie City (PA) School District and local Talent Search programs; 2) to disseminate the program structure and successes as a model for implementation; 3) to empower students to provide STEM solutions to local non-profit organizations, and 4) to increase the involvement of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM professions.

por.por_cntn:
In 2011, Gannon University was awarded a five-year NSF S-STEM grant: Award # 1153250; Title: Scholars of Excellence in Engineering and Computer Science (SEECS); Amount: $600,000; 07/01/2011 - 06/30/2017. Three goals were identified for the SEECS project: 1) increase the number of financially needy, academically talented students enrolling in and graduating from its engineering and computer science programs; 2) assist students to continue their education through graduation through a program of scholarships and rigorous academic support; and 3) foster professional development to prepare students for careers in STEM fields and graduate education. Five objectives were specified:

1)      Provide 20 scholarships per year for academically talented, financially disadvantaged STEM majors, especially those from underrepresented groups

2)      Build a referral network arrangement between Gannon University, the Erie City School District, and the local Talent Search programs to identify and recruit financially disadvantaged students who meet SEECS scholarship eligibility requirements

3)      Provide a program of academic and student service support that achieves an average 90% year-to-year retention rate for SEECS scholars

4)      Provide scholars with academic and professional development that prepares them for employment in a STEM field and/or graduate school

5)      Implement recruitment strategies to increase and maintain the number of women and underrepresented minorities at a minimum of 20% of the SEECS scholar

 

The cornerstone of the program was the Professional and Personal Enrichment Seminars which offered a single, shared experience for all scholars built around activities that address their personal and professional growth.  The seminars involved considerable interaction among scholars and with the PIs, thus enhancing the bond among scholars as a way of increasing retention.  Developmental workshops, offered by student support offices, built social, academic, and career skills.  In line with the University’s commitment to community engagement, the seminar included a service-learning team design activity.  Paired with a community non-profit organization, the team of scholars identified and designed a solution to a STEM-related problem to aid the organization.  Such enrichment activities made the scholars more aware of the role of STEM professionals and helped them develop the social and leadership skills for their future careers.

 

SEECS Results: SEECS has successfully met its five objectives of providing scholarships to targeted students, building a referral network with the local school district, achieving a 90% year-to-year retention rate, and creating a professional development course for the scholars.  Finally, the program has achieved and maintained over 20% of women representation.  Table 1 provides the metrics to support the above statements.

Table 1: Summary SEECS II at Gannon University (2013-2016)

Four 3-year-cycle design projects were completed for regional non-profit organizations during this grant period.  These projects have had significant regional impact and have significant global implication, addressing both environmental and human needs.  Four students’ poster presentations, three at the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) North Central Section Conference (2014-16) and one at the 2017 ASEE Zone II Conference, occurred during the grant period showcasing their community-based design project. In addition, one work-in progress article was presented at the 2017 ASEE Zone II Conference title “Development and Design of a Medical Sterilizer for Mission Hospitals.”

During this grant period, one journal article (International Journal of Service Learning in Engineering) and four conference papers (ASEE Annual Meetings, ICEER Annual Conference, Frontiers in Education) have been published by the PIs reporting many aspects of the SEECS program. 

Finally, the impact of the program’s structure has met the intellectual merit and broader impact criteria of SEECS by having: (1) enhanced the disposition of the scholars towards engineering, service, and professionalism, (2) achieved retention objectives, (3) enabled collaborative PI-students scholarly activities, (4) disseminated the program structure and successes through professional outlets, thereby providing a model for implementation, (5) increased the involvement of women in STEM professions by continuing with successful recruitment practices, and (6) provided enrichment and professional development activities.

 


Last Modified: 09/19/2017
Modified by: Karinna M Vernaza

Paired with a community non-profit organization, the team of scholars identified and designed a solution to a STEM-related problem to aid the organization.  Such enrichment activities made the scholars more aware of the role of STEM professionals and helped them develop the social and leadership skills for their future careers.
